Worker.summary: The Worker interface of the Web Workers API represents a background task that can be created via script, which can send messages back to its creator.

remarks.para: Creating a worker is done by calling the Worker("path/to/worker/script") constructor.
Workers may themselves spawn new workers, as long as those workers are hosted at the same origin as the parent page.
Note that not all interfaces and functions are available to web workers. See Functions and classes available to Web Workers for details.

-Using Web Workers
-Functions and classes available to Web Workers
-Other kind of workers: and Service Worker.
-OffscreenCanvas interface

WorkerError.summary: The error event of the interface fires when an error occurs in the worker.

WorkerMessageerror.summary: The messageerror event is fired on a object when it receives a message that can't be deserialized.

remarks.para: This event is not cancellable and does not bubble.

WorkerMessage.summary: The message event is fired on a object when the worker's parent receives a message from its worker (i.e., when the worker sends a message using DedicatedWorkerGlobalScope.postMessage()).

remarks.para: This event is not cancellable and does not bubble.

WorkerPostMessage.summary: The postMessage() method of the interface sends a message to the worker. The first parameter is the data to send to the worker. The data may be any JavaScript object that can be handled by the structured clone algorithm.

remarks.para: The postMessage() method delegates to the method, which adds a task on the event loop corresponding to the receiving .
The Worker can send back information to the thread that spawned it using the method.

WorkerTerminate.summary: The terminate() method of the interface immediately terminates the . This does not offer the worker an opportunity to finish its operations; it is stopped at once.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGThis script passed to the url element is executed.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by having a Content Security Policy (CSP) that restricts the locations from which scripts can be loaded, and by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations for more information.
The Worker() constructor creates a object that executes the classic script or module at the specified URL.
